mods.note: USSSNI No. © Politico. Agency, Bahrain, 30th November 1944. To The Manager, Messrs. Gray Mackenzie & Co., Ltd., Bahrain. MaMOKANDUM Reference your mail notice for s. s. 'Esar.g' dated the 29th November 1944. 2. The official mail, from the Agency together with a box of plants for the Hon f ble the PolMcal Resident in the Persian Gulf was despatched from this Agency at 9-30 a^m and the farrash and the coolie carrying the box of plants proceeded direct to your office. I was informed at 12-40 p.i that the steamer had sailed without the mails and they were returned to me by one of your employees. My farrash states that he was detained ly your orders until 12-30 p.m. I shall be grateful If I can be furnished with an explanation why the steamer Left before the official mail had arrived. Political Agent, Bahrain, mtrnmrnmir ' ^ 9 A • /Iv^' 5 ' (\\ British India Steam Navigation Company Ltd, l ,\ y (incorporated in England; TELEGRAPHIC ADDRESS; gray. No. L/707. The Political Agent, BAHREIN. Dear sir, Bahrein, 2nd December, With reference to your letter No.3671 of the 30th ultimo, we have to advise Uiat the master of the ss. 'ESang' was informed that mails and passengers would be going aboard, at 10 a.m. q a., 30/11/44. The offloading of cargo was imisned at 1.30 a.m. and he sailed without instructions at 2 a.m., stating to the Supervisor on board that 'he could not wait'. . In the circumstances, the master of the 'Resang', then in port, was informed that passengers and mails would be aboard shortly after 10 a.m. At 10.10 a.m. five military passengers and the post office mail was taken aboard by our Mr. Pickering. No reference was made to the Agency regarding the non-arrival of mail at 10 a.m. as one bag had already been placed aboard tae 'Hesang' the previous evening. At 10.15 a.m. your farash arrived with a box of plants and one cover and he was sent in a car to the iwanama pier, to try and catch the launch. The launch, however, had left. The 'Hesang' sailed at 10.26 a.m. At 10.45 a bag of mail and a second cover was received. Mr. Pickering personally returned the farrash and mails to your Chief Clerk who stated that he thought tne box and cover might possibly have been in time but that the bag and second cover were undoubtedly late. yours faithfully. foi GRAY, MACl '/■t-jkit.tr p C< CO , LI X Agents.v n , N o .3((/D-13/14. \ Political Agency,\ Bahrain, 5th December 1944. To The Manager, Messrs, Gray Mackenzie & Co., Ltd., Bahrain. MEMORANDUM ■/' ' Reference your letter No.L/707 dated the 2nd December 1944. 2. I shall be grateful if you will obtain the captain of the 'Esang^s' explanation why he left the port with^the mail. 3. The mail for the ''Esang' 1 was despatched from here at 9-SO a.m. and it is not understood how it came about that it was not received by you before 10-15 a.m. The two individuals who carried the mail from here maintain that they arrived at your office well, before 10 o^lock. efr r , //. t/'— Political' Ag nt, Bahrain.No. ' r / ^- Political Agency, Bahrain, 11th December 1944. BAnrein, ^ecemoer, 19 44* J2. train Receipt AMkVato' The Political Agent, BAHREIN. f ^ ^ Dear Sir, ,<ith reference to your letter ^0.3756 of the 11th instant, we have to advise that as the ss. 'Barala' CjCfu<s~ was ft'axifr r| l' tfn to arrive here at 4 p.m. on the 10th and had only 179 tons cargo to discharge, it was expected that the ship would be ready to sail in the early hours of the .Llth instant. Mails were therefore called for at 6 p.m. on the lOth. You will remember that on a recent similar occasion, mails were not called for until 10 a.m. on the day after the arrival of the ship, but cargo work was actually finished before 2 a.m. Yours faithfully, for GRAY, MAGKCfJ~(E a-CO., LTD. The Company or any Telegraph Company or Government Telegraph Administration, by whom this telegram is or would in the ordinary course of the telegraphic service be forwarded, may decline to forward such telegram although it has been received for that purpose ; but in such case the amount paid for transmission will be refunded to the sender at his request. 2. Neither the Company nor any Telegraph Company, or Government Telegraph Administration, by whom this telegram is or would in the ordinary course of the telegraphic service be forwarded, nor any of their respective officers or servants shall be liable to make compensation for any loss, injury or damage arising or resulting from non-transmission or non-delivery of the telegram, or delay or error or omission in the transmission or delivery thereof, through whatever cause such non-transmission, non-delivery, delay, error, or omission shall have occurred even though occasioned by the neglect or default of such Company or Administration or any officer or servant in their employ. 3. This telegram shall be forwarded in accordance with the provisions of the International Telegraph Regulations and the provisions of such Regulations shall be deemed to be binding between the sender and this or any Telegraph Company or Government Telegraph Administration by whom this telegram is or would in the ordinary course of the telegraphic service be forwarded. 4. The* above mentioned conditions also apply to telegrams tendered to or delivered by the Company by telephone, over a private line, or by any other means whatsoever. NOTE.—Code words used in the text of telegrams must not contain more than 5 letters. The use of accented letters is not permitted in code words. By International Regulations, the sender of a telegram is obliged to produce the code from which the text or part of the text in code has been compiled if requested by the office of origin. If figures and groups of figures, including commercial marks containing figures and letters, are used in code telegrams directed to extra-European destinations, their number, reckoned iw accordance with the Rules for charging, must not exceed one half of the number of chargeable words in the text and signature. Political Resident at Shiraz. 663 5th September, 1945< No up mail since 4th August and next ship not expected within 10 days. Grateful to know if any prospect improvement shipping in nea:- future. =P0LITICAL=' I IS Code. Government of India, New Delhi. Political Resident, Bushireo Political Agents, Kuwait, Bahrain and Muscat. Telegram From To Repeated No.428. Dated 15th received 16th January, 1946. As over one thousand returning Shia pilgrims had become stranded at Basra, Government of India have had to commandeer a large part of deck space available on Barjora which left Basra January 12th and Barala leaving at the end 4 of the month. Government of India may be compelled to take similar action in respect of one or two more sdilings also. Government of India greatly regret inconvenience which will inevitably result to prospective deck passengers at inter mediate ports. LEI. I.R.No.20. BAHREIN- TO Hie political Agent, mm.MK' No. Bl/S-S^ 6 ' hAr»»o HwP', istji jnua, S «Wt>.» Dear Sir, DECK P/iSSENGERS We have to inform you that 250 Deck passages were allotted for Bahrein requirenaen-Uper s-s^'Barpeta 51 which arrived here on the 14th instant, but we have only been able to book 240 persons including 70 public passengers. as nearly 200 public passengers were registered in our books, for transport to India, and in view of the fact that these passengers did not apply for tickets on arrival of the vessel, we are cancelling their names from our v /aiting list. In future, therefore, no register will be kept by us and we shall revert to the system of issuing deck tickets to passengers on application as soon as we have definite information regarding arrival date of steamers aitf. our allottnttnt for deck accommodation. No. BI/S-141 BAHRAIN^ 16th pebruar-y, 193/47. \)L^ The political ^eaident, BAHRAIN. sir> We append below an extract of ou-f Bombay Amenta letter No*0/36 of 11/2/47 which is eelf explanatory;- rt s.s« rt BA t ?JORA H «*we would adviae that t4ie above vessel 9 on completion . of disch^r^e he^e, will be unde^goin^ junvey, ana ia not expected to be ^eaLiy to load fon pe^sian Qulf porta until early Ma-nch* Kindly pass this info-r4aation on to the political -^eaident You-ns faithfully, For GRAY, CKh^^ & O., LlO cc Political Bahraino f Bakain Recei^ AgentsFOB BKCt t 'S «rioa« inconvenience is being ceased to underOerthed . etSsengerB U'aveiling by the Company's eessel due to the excessive quantities of baggage by certain neabers of the trovsllinfe public* All und6rt>«rth«d ^8«engcr» •ndeevouring to e^rry them unduly large quantiti«» of baggag« and, particular! with , _ Tljf items which should pro parly be shipped a© cargo ara harcby informad that the Company reserves the right to refuse to accept such baggage on board the ressal and no responsibility whatsoever will be accepted for any expenses incurred as a resuit*^ For GRAY; MACKENZIE ^ -o., Llo Bahr 24 th hracnt April,47. RAY; M —. B.X.3.N.C0.LXD* Ageriu, / , ■-» .B ritish I ndia S team N avigation C ompany L td. (incorporated in England; TELEGRAPHIC ADDRESS; GRAY. No. Bahrein, 6th iiu^ust ls47 19 Political rk^entj Bahre in • D^ar Sirs1 AMmmK. The second of the new vessels Intended tor the British India Company's service between Bombay Karachi and Persian Gulf ports, namely the *& w ^ bka *, is expected to arrive in Bombay on the 26th July 15*47, and will shortly thereafter Join her sister ship the *DUM3&* on this service* You will no doubt be interested in the fallowing part iculars j - t*- The although of mode re te siae Judged by midern standards, is s compact and completely fitted liner able to serve hera owners on one of their various services* Indeed, when going over the ship it is difficult to realise that her tonnage is but 4,867 gross* The ^DWA^Sw 11 carries twenty first and thirty second class passengers and up tol,000 unberthed pass* angers between Bombay Karachi an# Persian Gulf ports, where the sea affords the quickest and most convenient form of transport* The first c&ass passengers have single or two-berth cabins, as spacious as those of a large liner and they have too their own lounge, a amUe room and bar and a dining saloon* The cabins have hot and cold running water, ample cupboard space and effective ventialtion; even curtains to draw around your bed in case your companion in the other berth has his light on when you wish to s Isep* The second passengers have a standards of comfort in thsir accommodation comparing favourably with the first class of a generation ago*^v tmrt* B ritish I ndia S team N avigation C ompany L td h (incorporated in England; TELEGRAPHIC ADDRESS: GRAY. no, 19 - 8 - They too have a charmingly fumiahad lounge and a dining saloon whilst the three-berth cabins in which they aleep are unusually roomy• The unberthed passengera will be well loolcad after and every reooauaendation of the oonferencea at Seattle end Simla has been complied with, and in aome caaee exceeded* This daae of paaaenger is y often unable to understand the uaual notices f and stancilled signs are put in appropiate places to assist the new comer* The Indian members of the crew have excellent quartera aft| being housed in four to eig!ht*berth cab ins | wiUi apeciAl single cabjns for the Serangs* JSech sectian y deck, engine room end stewards 9 has its own cooking facilities with modem oil-fired arranges and its own meas room. The cubic space per man required by the Government of India has everywhere been exceeeded* as might be expected, the is well fitted for tropical 6ervice 9 eapecially in the important matter of ventilation* There is 9 too, plenty of deck apace in each class* Ihe 'OltiKKA* has four cargo holds, each fitted with two derricks one of which will lift twenty-five tons* 3ome 200 *000 cubic feet of stowage apace is available! with, 3 f 000 cubic feet for refrigerated stores* She is a motor-ship with Ooxfor type, opposed piston engines developing 4.200 brake horae-power giving a service speed of fourteen knots* Yours faithfully, GRAY, MACKENZIE A CO* LTD*, Agents*COPY BRITISH INDIA STEAM NAVIGATION COMPANY LTD., BAHRAIN, No • BI/S/CIR CULAR/785 7th July, 1949 His Excellency the Political Resident in the Persian Gulf, Sir Rupert Hay, K.C.I.E., C.S.I Jufair . Dear Sir, We are pleased to be able to advise that the Company have arranged for a monthly direct ser vice from the Persian Gulf to Japan and vice-versa commencing with m.v. 'PUNDUA' expected to be ready to load in the Persian Gulf about the middle of July. This vessel's itinerary will be from Basrah to Yokohama via Khorramshahr, Persian Gulf Ports as inducement offers, Karachi, Bombay, Cochin, Colombo, Penang, Port Swettenham, Singapore, Hong Kong, Kobe, Yokohama. PERSIAN GULF/JAPAN Yours faithfully, W. Meikle. For Gray Mackenzie & Co. Ltd., Agents, B.I.S.N. Co. Ltd.Ul Political Agency, Bahrain, No,R-345-3/14 July 21, 1949. Doar Gethin, ^^8 Your complimentary slip No.24]y F/49 of July 11 (received here on July 16). Somebody oulc presumably report this to the Foreign Office. Do you propose to do so? i It would be preferable in future cases of this nature if you would say on the complimentary slip what action you have taken or want us to take. Yours ever, H.a. Jakins J.A.P. Gethin, Esq. ; Persian Gu-f Residency, Bahrain.PERSIAN GULF RESIDENCY, BAHRAIN, 3rd Aug-utt, 1949. (123/38/49) ' I A 7 It ®) i ^-^7^ 3> Please refer to your letter R-345- 3/14 of July 21, paragraph 2. I had already arranged that compli mentary slips will be used in future to pass papers for information and retention only. In any case where action is required a covering letter will be sent, I apologise for the inconvenience caused by the previous procedure. H.G. Jakins, Esq., Political Agent, Bahrain.Issued letter No.3571 dated 30-11-44 to the Manager, Messrs. Gray Mackenzie, Bahrain, Letter lIo.L/707 dated 2-12-44 from Messrs. Gray Mackenzie,Bahrain . A. P. A. P. A. The bag sent to Gray Mackenzie on the 29th November contained seven parcels of seeds from Poocha, Poona for the Secretary. It was actually received by Gray, Mackenzie's at 12.00 hours (vide receipt enclosed). The mail bag containing private letters for the staff of the Residency^ two official letters and a box o plants were definitely sent from here at 9-30 a.m. and I cannot understand why the peon took 45 minutes when he- went straight to Gray Mackenzie. Mr. Moorthv brought one bag at 10-15 a.m. and gave it to Mr. Christdas for despatch. He reported to me and I told Mr. Moorthy that it was too late but I telephoned to Gray Mackenzie and told them that another bag was on its way to their office. Mr. Pickering came to my office after 12-30 noon with mails and told me that the ship had sailed. I told him that one bag with the box of plants was sent in time but the second bag was undoubtedelate as it was sen- from here at 10-15 whereas the mils were required at 10 a.m. in his office. I have instructed the Desi^atch Clerk that in future he should send all mails before one hour they are required by Gray Mackenzie and telephone to Gray Mackenzie that mails are being sent. ^Av>ri . fA , > • V

location.physicalLocation: British Library: India Office Records and Private Papers

titleInfo.title: 'File 3/14 III Arrival and departure of ships and B.I.S.N. sailings'

physicalDescription.extent: The papers are arranged chronologically from the front to the rear of the file.
Foliation: the foliation system in use is the sequence of numbers appearing in the top right hand corner of each page. Foliation anomalies: 2, 2a; 14, 14a; 21, 21a; 43, 43a (folio 43a is unfoliated).

mods.abstract: Correspondence concerning the arrrival and departure of mail ships and British India Steam Navigation Company Ltd. Steamships for transport of slow mail included the Baralaand the Barjora. One letter describes how the Government of India commandeered deck space for a thousand returning Shia pilgrims stranded at Basra; also the start of a service to and from Japan. Correspondents include the Political Agent, Bahrain; Gray, Mackenzie and Co. Ltd; British India Steam Navigation Company Ltd; Political Resident Persian Gulf; Political Agent, Muscat.

name.namePart: British India Steam Navigation Company Limited
